Allen directed this unique film about one's nostalgic yearning to be living in a time-gone-by rather than present-day. There were a few stretches where I hoped the story would pick up, but the clever twists and humourous trips back to reality kept my attention. Wilson felt miscast at first as Gil, a successful screenwriter and struggling novelist. However, his intentional naivety and ignorance ended up being well-suited for the character. This film will be appreciated more by artists of all kinds as Gil's Bohemian dreams won't universally resonate with the general public. The relationship between Gil and his fiancée (played by McAdams) was so figuratively destructive that it became an added element of the film's subtle humour and I selfishly hoped they would stay together.

Gil (Owen Wilson) is Hollywood script writer and Inez (Rachel McAdams) is his fiancé, they are an American couple who come to Paris for Inez' parents' business trip. Gil loves Paris and wishes that after his upcoming wedding he could actually live there with Inez, even though she wants to go to Malibu and make Gil continue his Hollywood script writer career even though he doesn't like that and is now in the middle of finishing a novel. Inez goes dancing with some friends at midnight and Gil decides to go for a walk, with that walk he wasn't just inspired for his novel, he also entered the heart of Paris. Gil now goes for a walk every day and while he keeps getting more interested in Paris, he also keeps losing interest on his wife.(What I though about the plot) I loved the plot, it has fantastic things in it, it was amazingly well written by Woody Allen who actually won an Oscar for it, but as always, he wasn't there for recieve it, but whathever, I think that this is a genius plot and it worked really well in this fantastic movie, trust me. Great plot.

Soundtrack, well, I loved this movie's soundtrack, I think there was just two themes, but two fantastic themes that I did not got tired of hearing, this movie really had a great soundtrack.

Besides all that, I am now going to tell you what I really thought about this movie. First of all, before I watched it, I really wanted to see it and after reading several positive reviews for this movie, I had no doubts that I was going to like it. I just loved this movie, it's diferent from all of the movies that Woody has direct before, this movie has a certain fantasy as an atmosphere of life and love, this is a genius work. This movie is ment to be watched during the entire minutes, you can't even blink your eyes, cause if you're not used to the characters, you're experinece will be diferent. Sow, what can I say, I loved the movie, it's about Paris, love and life, it's about everything and I just loved it, trust me, it's no chick flick, there's no stupid romance or cliche, it's really just ment for all movie lovers, man or woman, this has to be watched by everyone. Overall, this is a fantastic movie, it has a great cast, a great plot, a great soundtrack and it's very entertaining. Defenitly one of my favorite movies, this movie goes much beyond than just a Woody Allen rom-com. Fantastic.

In "Midnight in Paris," Gil(Owen Wilson), a Hollywood screenwriter, and his fiancee Inez(Rachel McAdams) are guests of her parents(Kurt Fuller & Mimi Kennedy) in Paris.  While Gil is seduced by the city's charms, she falls under the charms of Paul(Michael Sheen, playing a different kind of vampire this time around), a former professor.  Wanting to see more of the city, Gil decides to walk back to his hotel after dinner one night.  And then gets so lost that he runs into Zelda(Alison Pill) and Scott(Tom Hiddleston) who take him barhopping.  Along the way, he chats with Ernest Hemingway(Corey Stoll) who offers to pass along his unpublished novel to Gertrude Stein(Kathy Bates) to read the next time he sees her.

As rough a recent track record as he has, the one consistency of Woody Allen's career is how well he has always fared with fantasy(I haven't seen "Scoop" and no intention to) and "Midnight in Paris" is no different, as it is an engaging and bittersweet love letter to a city, with a tip of the hat to Mark Twain's 'A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court.'  It is also a neat history lesson with some superb references, including one very cool cinematic one, where great figures of art and literature interact with each other, with Adrien Brody making for a very strange Salvador Dali.(Although maybe that's the point.)  Just remember that while the past may be a great place to visit, you would not want to live there; just as Woody Allen points out how the present looks back to the past as a golden age, not realizing we may live in one as I write this which we can do much to confirm with our actions.
Definitely a bit odd but still sooo good. Great acting and visuals (cinematography, production design, and costumes) but the story is what drives this great movie.

WRITERS OF HOLLYWOOD!.. please hear my plea. Stop putting two dimensional super bitches in your films in an attempt to get the audience on the side of your protagonist. It doesn't work, its just annoying! 
Okay.. phew..

This along with a host of other things is wrong with midnight in paris. So much is wrong, in fact, that i was flabber-ghasted upon checking RT halfway through my viewing (to get some catharsis for my frustrations by reading the other scathing reviews i expected to find) when instead of such reviews i found this stinking pile of a film has merited 93%!?

Now, perhaps its an egging thing. By an egging thing i mean, fans of Woody Allen egging on the film, whisping off all its faults like Gil may have flapped his way through the thick hanging cigar and opium clouds of his cartoon, romantic, 1920's Paris. I must admit, as a fan i am liable to do the same for directors and actors i desperately want to see succeed. 

But really, lets step out of the magic time car for a second, lets step back to reality. 

The characters were cartoonish and Gil was boring. The film was put together like it was made for the tourist board of Paris (who would have LOVED it) imagine every american sit-coms obligatory 'London calling' UK trip montage and you'll get the gist.  I didn't care what happened to anyone involved. The only interesting plot point, the idea of stepping into a number of mysterious time cars and travelling to a number of ages we all have romanticisms about, was not used! And now will never be! It is the worst artistic crime to take a good idea, and just smush it into the dust just so. Potential ruined. 

We were asked politely to let the main conceit go and accept Gils situation (no problem Mr Allen, fair enough) the problem with this film came with its indulgent tendency to just pass things over to the audience for their immediate acceptance, it seems, in all cases. 

We were never given a reason why Gil was with his horrible fiance in the first place, okay so.. you just are then?; We were never given a history of Inez and the pedant, sorry.. how do you know each other again? Oh yeah, collage.. yeah.. .. okay; a few minutes with Gil and beautiful fantasy Parisienne ladies were falling at his feet. Im sorry.. HUH?!

I understand the point Allen was trying to get across, the grass is always greener blah blah blah. I really don't care.

Highly praised by the critics and awarded the Oscar for Best Writing, Original Screenplay for Woody Allen; I really couldnâ(TM)t pass this one up when it premiered on TV this week. I was a little sceptical having seen a couple of Allenâ(TM)s more recent works and being a tad less than impressed, but I neednâ(TM)t have worried. It seems those critics do get it right now and then and I have to say I really enjoyed this one. Hereâ(TM)s a very brief summary before I give you my thoughts.

Gil (Owen Wilson) is a writer; he has been to Paris in the past and loves the place; his fiancÃ (C)e, Inez (Rachel McAdams), hasnâ(TM)t. She doesnâ(TM)t share his love of the city and in particular doesnâ(TM)t get his fixation with Paris in the 1920â(TM)s. Her parents, John (Kurt Fuller) and Helen (Mimi Kennedy) are also there, partly on business and partly to help with wedding plans. They meet some friends of Inez, Paul (Michael Sheen) and Carol (Nina Arianda), who insist on taking them out so Paul can show off his extensive knowledge of the city. Gil finds it all terribly dull and decides to walk back to their hotel one night. He gets lost as pauses at the side of a particular street as the church clock chimes midnight. An old car comes up the road and a group of revellers persuade him to come with them. He find himself in a bar talking to the likes of F. Scott Fitzgerald (Tom Hiddleston), Zelda Fitzgerald (Alison Pill) and even Ernest Hemmingway (Corey Stoll). Oh, and thereâ(TM)s a girl (thereâ(TM)s always a girl), Adriana (Marion Cotillard). He is in the 1920â(TM)s Paris he always dreamed of, but how? And what lies around the corner?... Guess Iâ(TM)d better leave it there.

We begin with shots of Paris (yes, some of them in the rain) and I think Iâ(TM)m looking at a travelogue; but Iâ(TM)m wrong. Once it gets going this film is very witty and even whimsical at times, and I really enjoyed it. Woody Allenâ(TM)s writing is spot on here with some great dialogue and some marvellous characters. The plot has just the right amount of mystery to keep me interested and even has some important points about living your life in the past. All the performances were excellent with Owen Wilson and Marion Cotillard getting top marks from me. Over all I found it very entertaining, amusing and even a little profound in placesâ¦ Well worth a look!

SteelMonsterâ(TM)s verdict: HIGHLY RECOMMENDED

It's a sign of the sad depths to which Woody Allen's career has fallen that this slightly-better-than mediocre film has been hailed as his best work in years.  The premise is amusing, if slight and under-realized by the script, which begins as an interesting examination of history's tendency to file down the past from a complex world inherited by three-dimensional human beings into a simple narrative inhabited by stock characters before reverting to a typically Allenesque and far less intriguing dramatization of the romantic disappointments of neurotic upper class New York liberals.  But Owen Wilson is woefully miscast as a wannabe novelist obsessed with the Lost Generation era, and the gifted Rachel McAdams is utterly wasted in a one-note role as his shrill, unlikable fiancee.  And it is not not half as funny or insightful as it wants to be.  It's great that Allen has made an okay movie instead of an awful one, but hardly cause for celebration.

Literally saw this movie but several minutes ago, and I have to say I've already found a new addition to my list of favorite movies. As I've seen lately, great movies using Paris as a backdrop or setting at some point have become a commodity for directors once again. Case in point: Ratatouille, Inception, Les Intouchables and this movie. This one is probably the most important of all because of its depiction of a writer falling quickly in love with the city and its people, despite his company's cynicism and ignorance. "If I'm not mistaken..." Woody Allen did make a film set in Paris in 1996, and his love for the city (played vicariously through Owen Wilson, I am sure) shows throughout the film. Speaking of Owen Wilson, and declaring myself a non-fan, I actually found that he fit the role perfectly. All other casting was perfect as well, and I feel that Rachel McAdams fits a role such as this one better than, say, Irene Adler in Sherlock Holmes. I am also convinced that Woody Allen must have based the characters of Inez, her parents, Carol and Paul (the "pedantic one") off of real-life character. The scenes featuring them at Paris during the daytime are perfectly acted/scripted. Well done, Woody Allen; certainly your best work in years.

An infectiously fun film with a memorable performance from Owen Wilson.
Highly creative, highly enjoyable, touching... love it!
It's not among Woody's all-time best, but it's still plenty good.
Haven't seen a more old fashioned and better movie for a long time. It is one of the films I can watch again and again.
Unexpected and charming, I love movies that step outside the box and Midnight in Paris did just that!
Beautiful movie with so many great actors

Its just interesting to see a bunch of dead creative types come to life in this movie. A very nicely concepted movie where two people of different ages meet through a time leap and does yet another time leap to realise that there is no golden age and that the hankering for the ideal past is really just in the mind. Carpe diem.
Paris is charming,as like this film,'Midnight in Paris'is quite entertaining and sometimes enjoyable.
classic Woody Allen doing his thang
A Woody Allen Love affair with Paris, beautifully shot and full of style
Simple and enjoyable, It's Woody Allen at his contemporary best
I think Woody Allen movies are better when the Woody Allen part is played by someone other than Woody Allen. Worth seeing for the beauty of Paris and the scene stealing of Hemmingway alone.

Woody's love letter to Paris. Reminded me of his Manhattan in that respect. One big difference, the hero in this later movie is a lot smarter than Woody was in Manhattan, or maybe Woody is more the hopeless romantic now than he was then. Here the hero gets the girl in the end instead of pushing her away like Woody did to Muriel in Manhattan. Anyway, I enjoyed this movie, both the beauty of the place and the concept of the advantages and disadvantages of living in another, presumably golden, age.
The greatest movie i have ever seen !!!
Ever thougt how would your life be if you would meet your idols? This film is an answer to that question.

This is the most nostalgic and elegant movie i have ever seen.
the sets and locations of fantastic Paris are perfect.

i really loved the concept of time travelling to 1920's 1890's and so on.
Must say the best screenplay of the year and movie too.

Biggest mistake I ever did was seeing it after I just got back from Paris.
Never watched a woody Allen pic until this one and I loved the quirkiness, the gorgeous setting, play with time travel, and subtle jabs at America vs Europe culture.
Awesome story, screenplay and direction from Woody Allen...!

I loved this movie.  So clever, so fun, so romantic.  Made me want to go to Paris.  Owen Wilson was wonderful as a young man who wonders if having another life in another time would be better.  The time travel made the movie for me.

A great comeback for Woody, but a little to nostalgia-laden.  The various cameos by the artist elite at that time make it fun, but not enough to overcome the lack of anything to say.  Visually stunning, well acted, and a great director on his form, but what's the point?
Watching this movie is like having the absolutely best dream I could ever imagine.
